abstract.p: He is waiting to hear about the requirements for the MB examination before considering the possible trip to north America.

div.p: I would have written to you before but I have been writing to St Georges (to my friend there) to find out whether I could get away from London before the end of July & whether I need come back at the beginning of October— I am afraid I couldn’t get away till end of July— but I am almost sure that I might come back about the middle of Oct I will tell you when I hear— It is most awfully kind of you to offer to pay for me— I dont know what the exped wd cost but I should certainly have a great deal of my July to Oct allowance to spend on it—so I hope you wdnt have to help me much Will you please let me have the remainder of my £100; because you have given me such an awful lot of extra money, that I very much want to do with as little as possible— If I find I cant manage to go to America & keep my London Hosp term of course I must give it up— I had quite made up my mind that I wasnt going so it wouldn’t be much disappointment—
I have 5 guineas fees to pay, so will you please pay that with the remainder of the £100 sometime before the end of the term

div.note: Top of letter: ‘(Eye of Cuttlefish) | Pryor Artic | Review | Balfour’ pencil
The date is established by the relationship between this letter and the letter to Francis Darwin, 16 May [1871].

Francis’s friend was probably Edward Charles Stirling, a fellow student at St George’s Hospital, London (see first letter from Francis Darwin, [after 22 May 1871]). Francis was hoping to travel to the United States in the summer with his brother George Howard Darwin and two friends (see letter from G. H. Darwin, [14 May 1871]).
